#Text=Wikimania 2008 : MediaWiki use in the U.S. Department of State
#Text=This article mentions the Wikimedia Foundation , one of its projects , or people related to it .
#Text=Wikinews is a project of the Wikimedia Foundation .
#Text=Sunday , July 20 , 2008
#Text=The last day of the Wikimania 2008 conference saw Saturday morning sessions on a variety of topics .
#Text=Wikinews attended a presentation by Eric M. Johnson from the United States Department of State .

#Text=Eric , a former NCO in the U.S. Marines , is the lead for the Knowledge Management Action team in the department 's Office of eDiplomacy , and involved in department 's use of Web 2.0 technologies for knowledge management .
#Text=This includes blogs , and the key focus of his talk , Wiki culture in the U.S. Department of State .
#Text=Eric opened his presentation with an introduction to the U.S. State Department , one of the oldest agencies of the American government , which today has around 57,000 employees worldwide .
#Text=When formed in the 18th century their offices and diplomatic staff operated largely autonomously due to lack of ability to communicate rapidly .

#Text=By the mid-20th century this had changed with the advent of telegraph lines , and changed again with the Cold War and security concerns bringing to the fore the well-known term , " need to know " .

#Text=Now , in the 21st century , the volume of internal communication generated by the department is a staggering 1,800,000 cables a year , 1.5 billion emails , production of around 500,000 print volumes , and maintenance of approximately one thousand websites .
#Text=Both internal and externally facing .

#Text=A pilot project was set up , Diplopedia , a MediaWiki wiki running on the department 's internal network , which outside of the department of defence is one of the largest private networks operated by the U.S. government .
#Text=A grassroots effort , this project to promote knowledge sharing differs from the well-known Wikipedia in that it does not allow anonymous edits .
#Text=There are around 1,000 registered users who have contributed over 4,400 pages .
#Text=Integration with the Department of State 's internal search engine prioritises results from the wiki , increasing the popularity of the site such that it has received over 650,000 page views .

#Text=Like Wikipedia , users are required to provide sources for entered information at the foot of the article , and users are warned that it is a starting point and not an authoritative source of information .
#Text=Data on visa requirements and information from other static department sites has been incorporated into the wiki .
#Text=Eric described the project as just reaching critical mass and attracting increasing interest from other departments .

#Text=Among the ingredients leading to the success of the project were the cultural change with increasing awareness of the technology from Wikipedia , the formation by the community of a welcoming committee , and the taking on of roles to carry out tasks such as drafting .
#Text=A number of staff act as " gardeners " tending to the wiki content , keeping it fresh , and well cross-referenced .
#Text=The continual updating is a novel concept to many of their employees .
#Text=Unlike Wikipedia , and many other projects using MediaWiki , none of the Diplopedia pages are locked or protected .
#Text=This even includes their main page .

#Text=To date there have been none of the content disputes that have been an issue on Wikipedia , and the use of the wiki to replace traditional websites which are far more time consuming to maintain is seen as a logical extension of the project .

#Text=Carried out with no outside help , and by learning from others ' mistakes , the department has adopted mechanisms for assuming that contributions are well-intentioned , and has a body for oversight in the event of a dispute .
#Text=With the success of the project , eDiplomacy plans to introduce a separate , classified wiki .
#Text=They will also expand the effort to compile biographies of foreign leaders , which was pioneered by the U.S. missions in Italy and Germany .
#Text=This effort has proven valuable when combined with a version of the site available on portable devices such as the Blackberry .
#Text=The future holds moves to seek more support from management and integration with their primary authentication system .
#Text=Among the features on the main page to keep the project interesting to staff is a " Diploquiz " which poses a weekly trivia question which can be answered from somewhere within the wiki .
